primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The movement from being enslaved by the spiritual power of money to being liberated by the gospel of the 'Ultimate Rich Young Ruler' (Jesus).

subject.identificatie: Jesus Christ (The Ultimate Rich Young Ruler)
tekstueel_bewijs: I’m going to love you enough to give away the most incredible wealth anyone has ever given up
Jesus Christ... gave up everything for you

object.identificatie: The heart of the hearer (liberation from idolatry/security in God)
tekstueel_bewijs: so that you can have the only wealth that lasts, God himself
your money will become just money. It won’t be your identity anymore.
The gospel changes the way in which we look at our money
Thank you, Father, for your generosity to us.

ontvanger.identificatie: The Hearer (specifically the 'Rich Young Ruler' in the pew)
tekstueel_bewijs: so that you can have the only wealth that lasts
He did it all for the love of you.

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit/Gospel Insight (The 'Melting' of the heart)
tekstueel_bewijs: until it catches fire and begins to melt your hard heart
the resources for deep, infinite comfort and joy
money has great spiritual danger attached to it
money was his identity, his living water
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Money is treated not just as currency but as a 'spiritual power' that addicts, blinds, and replaces God as the source of life.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the believer: Radical generosity and sacrificial giving.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.object: The Poor / The Neighbor / The Church
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (giving) is explicitly presented as a consequence of the primary program (being loved by Christ). Ethics follows soteriology.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: Gospel/Spirit → Jesus Christ ← Sin/Idolatry of Wealth

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Pouvoir' (Power) provided by the Gospel to overcome the 'Impossibility' of human effort. It moves from Devoir (Law) to Pouvoir (Grace).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: S2 (Rich Ruler's failure) → ~S1 (Pharisee's legalism) → S1 (Christ's sacrifice) → ~S2 (The believer's new capacity to give).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension of 'impossibility' is resolved by the 'Subject-switch' where Jesus becomes the Rich Ruler who succeeds where the human ruler failed.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The sermon emphasizes that salvation is 'literally impossible' for man.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon discusses money and giving (ethical topics), it grounds the ability to give entirely in the substitutionary work of Christ and the transformation of the heart's 'living water'.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: In the Old Testament, it was a minimum of 10 percent.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: I wasn’t talking about that rich young ruler. There are two rich young rulers in this story.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: Grace as the source of Power
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: It will be a joy to the degree that you grasp what the ultimate rich young ruler did for you.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The biblical figure (Rich Young Ruler) is used as a mirror of failure, not a model for imitation. Jesus is the only 'model', but primarily as a Savior.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: None (The ruler is a negative example)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God does what man cannot.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and gratitude leading to spontaneous action, rather than guilt-driven duty.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Justification by grace alone precedes the life of sanctification (generosity).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'danger of money' to the 'work of Christ' is logically and narratively seamless.
spanning_punten: The tension between the '10% rule' and 'sacrificial giving' creates a slight modal shift back to Devoir at the very end.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: I’m going to be stripped of my Father’s love... and I’m going to do it all for the love of you.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (implied through the Gospel) melts the heart to provide the 'Vouloir' (will) and 'Pouvoir' (power) to give.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is seen as a 'tumor' and an 'addiction' that renders human effort 'impossible'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully avoids moralism by making Jesus the 'Hero' of the story who fulfills the requirements the hearer cannot meet.

identificatie_herstel.strategie: The preacher already identifies the hearer as the 'helpless rich ruler' and Jesus as the 'successful rich ruler'.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly heavy on Devoir (Must/Rules) in the final 2 minutes.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the 'Pouvoir' (Gospel power) focus even when discussing the tithe.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Frame the 10% not as a 'rule of thumb' but as a 'response-metric' of a heart already freed.

tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The 'Opponent' (Money as an idol) is sufficiently 'heavy' to require a divine Subject.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in avoiding the 'Exemplarism' trap. By identifying Jesus as the 'Other' Rich Young Ruler, the preacher moves the sermon from a lecture on financial ethics to a proclamation of the Gospel.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'camel' metaphor; Greimas focuses on why the camel makes human agency (Subject) impossible.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the 'eye of the needle'; Greimas explains the functional role of that impossibility in the narrative of salvation.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'Subject' of the sermon's climax is not the hearer giving money, but Christ giving His life, which then re-enables the hearer as a secondary Subject.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Law' to crush the 'Subject-Hearer' before introducing the 'Subject-Christ'.
